Shout out to Moriah Lippert for earning a spot on the 2020 Minnesota Speech Coaches Association All-State Speech Team! üéâüôå

‚ÄúI am very proud of Moriah; she has been a force on the Maple River Speech Team for the last six years, and she will be greatly missed!‚Äù said Gwen Isaacson, Maple River Speech Coach.

In the Minnesota Speech Coaches Association (MSCA) press release, they recognized 117 speech competitors. To qualify for All-State recognition, speakers must achieve a series of milestones established by the MSCA. Those qualifications include being a senior in high school, documented excellence in competition, including competing on subsection/section teams and at least one appearance at the MSHSL State Speech Tournament, and utilizing their speech skills in at least three other activities, such as National Honor Society, dramatics, or athletics. Community engagement is also part of the qualifying criteria.

Congratulations, Moriah, on earning this recognition!

In the past, agricultural land owners and school districts in rural Minnesota faced major challenges to fund facilities. As a way to provide agricultural land owners with tax relief, the 2019 Minnesota State Legislature passed an amendment that will increase the Ag2School tax credit on school bonds from 40% to 70% over the next three years. The credit will increase to 55% for taxes payable in 2021, 60% in 2022, and 70% in 2023 and thereafter.

With the Ag2School tax credit paying for 51% of the total project over the life of the bond, local taxpayers will pay less than half of the $63.3M project cost.

Minnesota taxpayers contribute to the State of Minnesota's General Fund, however, Blue Earth County taxpayers pay less than 1% of the income taxes paid to the State of Minnesota. Over 60% of the Ag2School funding originates in the 7-county metropolitan area (Anoka, Carver, Dakota, Hennepin, Ramsey, Scott and Washington counties.)

For an estimate of your individual tax impact, visit the tax calculator page: https://www.isd2135.k12.mn.us/domain/306

After the 2018 bond referendum failed, we knew that we had to go back to the drawing board and create a plan that meets the needs of the community while addressing the financial challenges of operating our aging buildings.

To gauge the support of the community, we worked with School Perceptions LLC, an independent firm, to conduct a community survey. Fifty-seven percent of people that participated support building a PK-12th grade facility to serve all students. With your feedback, we are seeking a fourth referendum to build one facility that will support the future generations of Maple River.

In the 2019 legislative session, state legislators passed an amendment that will increase the Ag2School tax credit on school bonds to 70% over the next three years. Join us in the coming months to discuss how this opportunity can benefit students, teachers and the Maple River community.

Update: Surveys were mailed out this week.

The Maple River School Board is reaching out to all district residents with a community-wide survey to gather input regarding future plans for school facilities. Since 2015, the District has been trying to determine the best solution to address the aging school buildings and declining enrollment. The survey will ask residents to weigh in on the future plans.

To assist in gathering data, the School Board is working with School Perceptions LLC, an independent firm with expertise in conducting school district surveys. Every household will receive a paper survey in the mail. Residents can either complete the paper survey and mail it back in the envelope provided, or log on to the website listed and take the survey online. The survey is regulated by an access code that can be found within the mailed survey. Any additional surveys needed for other adults in the household can be requested by calling the District office and a second survey will be mailed out. All survey data is returned to School Perceptions and all responses remain anonymous.
